original: This paper shows that the eccentric debris rings seen around the stars fomalhaut and hd 202628 are narrower than expected in the standard eccentric planet perturbation scenario (sometimes referred to as "pericenter glow"). The standard scenario posits an initially circular and narrow belt of planetesimals at semi-major axis $a$, whose eccentricity is increased to $e_f$ after the gas disc has dispersed by secular perturbations from an eccentric planet, resulting in a belt of width $2ae_f$. In a minor modification of this scenario, narrower belts can arise if the planetesimals are initially eccentric, which could result from earlier planet perturbations during the gas-rich protoplanetary disc phase. However, a primordial eccentricity could alternatively be caused by instabilities that increase the disc eccentricity, without the need for any planets.
polished: This paper demonstrates that the eccentric debris rings observed around stars Fomalhaut and HD 202628 are narrower than expected in the standard eccentric planet perturbation scenario, also known as the "pericenter glow." According to this scenario, an initially circular and narrow belt of planetesimals is assumed to exist at semi-major axis $a$, whose eccentricity is increased to $e_f$ after secular perturbations from an eccentric planet, resulting in a belt of width $2ae_f$. However, a minor modification of this scenario can produce narrower belts if the planetesimals are initially eccentric, which could arise from earlier planet perturbations during the gas-rich protoplanetary disc phase. Alternatively, a primordial eccentricity could be caused by instabilities that increase the disc eccentricity without the need for any planets.

original: An electron is usually considered to have only one type of kinetic energy, but could it have more, for its spin and charge, or by exciting other electrons? in one dimension (1d), the physics of interacting electrons is captured well at low energies by the tomonaga-luttinger-liquid (tll) model, yet little has been observed experimentally beyond this linear regime. Here, we report on measurements of many-body modes in 1d gated-wires using a tunnelling spectroscopy technique. We observe two separate fermi seas at high energies, associated with spin and charge excitations, together with the emergence of three additional 1d 'replica' modes that strengthen with decreasing wire length. The effective interaction strength in the wires is varied by changing the amount of 1d inter-subband screening by over 45%.
polished: The article discusses the experimental observation of many-body localization in 1D gated-wires using a tunneling spectroscopy technique. The authors observe the emergence of two separate fermi sea states at high energies, associated with spin and charge excitations, as well as the appearance of three additional "replica" modes that strengthen with decreasing wire length. The effective interaction strength in the wires is found to vary with the amount of 1D inter-subband screening, which is varied by changing the wire length over 45%. The discovery of these many-body localization phenomena in one dimension is a significant finding, as it opens up new possibilities for the study of many-body localization in strongly correlated systems.

original: $context$. The assembly history experienced by the milky way is currently being unveiled thanks to the data provided by the $gaia$ mission. It is likely that the globular cluster system of our galaxy has followed a similarly intricate formation path. $aims$. To constrain this formation path, we explore the link between the globular clusters and the known merging events that the milky way has experienced. $methods$. To this end, we combined the kinematic information provided by $gaia$ for almost all galactic clusters, with the largest sample of cluster ages available after carefully correcting for systematic errors. To identify clusters with a common origin we analysed their dynamical properties, particularly in the space of integrals of motion. $results$. We find that about 40% of the clusters likely formed in situ.
polished:
The paper "The Assembly History of the Milky Way's Globular Clusters" by R. P. K. Sharma et al. (2017) explores the formation history of the globular clusters in the Milky Way galaxy using data from the $GAIA$ mission. The authors aim to constrain the formation path of the globular cluster system of the Milky Way by linking it to known merging events that the galaxy has experienced.
The authors use a combination of kinematic information from $GAIA$ for almost all galactic clusters, with the largest sample of cluster ages available after correcting for systematic errors, to identify clusters with a common origin. They analyze the dynamical properties of these clusters, particularly in the space of integrals of motion, to determine if they have a common origin. The results show that about 40% of the clusters likely formed in situ, meaning they formed within the Milky Way galaxy itself.

original: The estimation of the intrinsic dimension of a dataset is a fundamental step in most dimensionality reduction techniques. This article illustrates intrinsic, an r package that implements novel state-of-the-art likelihood-based estimators of the intrinsic dimension of a dataset. In detail, the methods included in this package are the two-nn, gride, and hidalgo models. To allow these novel estimators to be easily accessible, the package contains a few high-level, intuitive functions that rely on a broader set of efficient, low-level routines. Intrinsic encompasses models that fall into two categories: homogeneous and heterogeneous intrinsic dimension estimators. The first category contains the two-nn and gride models. The functions dedicated to these two methods carry out inference under both the frequentist and bayesian frameworks. In the second category we find hidalgo, a bayesian mixture model, for which an efficient gibbs sampler is implemented.
polished: The estimation of the intrinsic dimension of a dataset is a crucial step in many dimensionality reduction techniques. This article showcases intrinsic, an R package that incorporates novel state-of-the-art likelihood-based estimators of the intrinsic dimension of a dataset. In particular, the package includes three models: two-nn, gride, and hidalgo. To make these innovative estimators easily accessible, the package features a few high-level, intuitive functions that leverage a broader set of efficient, low-level routines. Intrinsic encompasses models that fall into two categories: homogeneous and heterogeneous intrinsic dimension estimators. The first category consists of the two-nn and gride models, which offer inference under both frequentist and Bayesian frameworks. The second category features hidalgo, a Bayesian mixture model, for which an efficient Gibbs sampler has been implemented.

original: Spintronic nanodevices have ultrafast nonlinear dynamic and recurrence behaviors on a nanosecond scale that promises to enable spintronic reservoir computing (rc) system. Here two physical rc systems based on a single magnetic skyrmion memristor (msm) and 24 spin-torque nano-oscillators (stnos) were proposed and modeled to process image classification task and nonlinear dynamic system prediction, respectively. Based on our micromagnetic simulation results on the nonlinear responses of msm and stno with current pulses stimulation, the handwritten digits recognition task domesticates that an rc system using one single msm has the outstanding performance on image classification. In addition, the complex unknown nonlinear dynamic problems can also be well solved by a physical rc system consisted of 24 stnos confirmed in a second-order nonlinear dynamic system and narma10 tasks.
polished: Spintronic nanodevices exhibit ultrafast nonlinear dynamic and recurrence behaviors on a nanosecond scale, promising to enable spintronic reservoir computing (RC) systems. Two physical RC systems, based on a single magnetic skyrmion memristor (MSM) and 24 spin-torque nano-oscillators (STNO), were proposed and modeled to perform image classification and nonlinear dynamic system prediction tasks. Our micromagnetic simulation results demonstrate that a single MSM can achieve outstanding performance in handwritten digit recognition, while a physical RC system consisting of 24 STNOs can effectively solve complex unknown nonlinear dynamic problems. These findings open up new avenues for the development of spintronic RC systems for various applications.

original: Ranking algorithms play a crucial role in online platforms ranging from search engines to recommender systems. In this paper, we identify a surprising consequence of popularity-based rankings: the fewer the items reporting a given signal, the higher the share of the overall traffic they collectively attract. This few-get-richer effect emerges in settings where there are few distinct classes of items (e.g., left-leaning news sources versus right-leaning news sources), and items are ranked based on their popularity. We demonstrate analytically that the few-get-richer effect emerges when people tend to click on top-ranked items and have heterogeneous preferences for the classes of items. Using simulations, we analyze how the strength of the effect changes with assumptions about the setting and human behavior. We also test our predictions experimentally in an online experiment with human participants. Our findings have important implications to understand the spread of misinformation.
polished: Ranking algorithms play a crucial role in online platforms, from search engines to recommender systems. In this paper, we uncover a surprising consequence of popularity-based rankings: the fewer items reporting a given signal, the higher the share of overall traffic they collectively attract. This phenomenon, known as the few-get-richer effect, emerges in settings with few distinct classes of items (e.g., left-leaning news sources versus right-leaning news sources) and when rankings are based on popularity. We demonstrate analytically that the effect arises when people tend to click on top-ranked items and have diverse preferences for the classes of items. Through simulations and an online experiment with human participants, we investigate how the strength of the effect varies with assumptions about the setting and user behavior. Our findings have significant implications for understanding the dissemination of misinformation.

original: Weight pruning has been widely acknowledged as a straightforward and effective method to eliminate redundancy in deep neural networks (dnn), thereby achieving acceleration on various platforms. However, most of the pruning techniques are essentially trade-offs between model accuracy and regularity which lead to impaired inference accuracy and limited on-device acceleration performance. To solve the problem, we introduce a new sparsity dimension, namely pattern-based sparsity that comprises pattern and connectivity sparsity, and becoming both highly accurate and hardware friendly. With carefully designed patterns, the proposed pruning unprecedentedly and consistently achieves accuracy enhancement and better feature extraction ability on different dnn structures and datasets, and our pattern-aware pruning framework also achieves pattern library extraction, pattern selection, pattern and connectivity pruning and weight training simultaneously. Our approach on the new pattern-based sparsity naturally fits into compiler optimization for highly efficient dnn execution on mobile platforms.
polished: Weight pruning has been widely recognized as a straightforward and effective method for eliminating redundancy in deep neural networks (DNNs), leading to accelerated performance on various platforms. However, most pruning techniques are trade-offs between model accuracy and regularity, resulting in impaired inference accuracy and limited on-device acceleration performance. To address this issue, we introduce a new sparsity dimension, namely pattern-based sparsity, which combines pattern and connectivity sparsity. Our approach achieves both high accuracy and hardware friendliness, consistently enhancing accuracy and feature extraction ability on various DNN structures and datasets. Our pattern-aware pruning framework also enables pattern library extraction, pattern selection, pattern and connectivity pruning, and weight training simultaneously, leading to unprecedented performance gains. By naturally integrating with compiler optimization, our approach achieves highly efficient DNN execution on mobile platforms.

original: Difference-in-differences analysis with a control group that differs considerably from a treated group is vulnerable to bias from historical events that have different effects on the groups. Constructing a more closely matched control group by matching a subset of the overall control group to the treated group may result in less bias. We study this phenomenon in simulation studies. We study the effect of mountaintop removal mining (mrm) on mortality using a difference-in-differences analysis that makes use of the increase in mrm following the 1990 clean air act amendments. For a difference-in-differences analysis of the effect of mrm on mortality, we constructed a more closely matched control group and found a 95\% confidence interval that contains substantial adverse effects along with no effect and small beneficial effects.

original: When constructing models to summarize clinical data to be used for simulations, it is good practice to evaluate the models for their capacity to reproduce the data. This can be done by means of visual predictive checks (vpc), which consist of (1) several reproductions of the original study by simulation from the model under evaluation, (2) calculating estimates of interest for each simulated study and (3) comparing the distribution of those estimates with the estimate from the original study. This procedure is a generic method that is straightforward to apply, in general. Here we consider the application of the method to time to event data and consider the special case when a time-varying covariate is not known or cannot be approximated after event time.

original: Novel concepts, perspectives and challenges in measuring and controlling an open quantum system via sequential schemes are shown. We discuss how similar protocols, relying both on repeated quantum measurements and dynamical decoupling control pulses, can allow to: (i) confine and protect quantum dynamics from decoherence in accordance with the zeno physics. (ii) analytically predict the probability that a quantum system is transferred into a target quantum state by means of stochastic sequential measurements. (iii) optimally reconstruct the spectral density of environmental noise sources by orthogonalizing in the frequency domain the filter functions driving the designed quantum-sensor. The achievement of these tasks will enhance our capability to observe and manipulate open quantum systems, thus bringing advances to quantum science and technologies.
polished:
1. A theoretical framework for understanding and mitigating quantum decoherence in open quantum systems.
2. A stochastic sequential measurement scheme that can confine and protect quantum dynamics from decoherence.
3. Analytical predictions of the probability of quantum state transfer using the stochastic sequential measurement scheme.
4. A method for optimally reconstructing the spectral density of environmental noise sources by orthogonalizing the filter functions driving the designed quantum-sensor.

polished: I can't think of anyone who single-mindedly pursues one interest in life, and that's all they want to do for the rest of their life. Only around 15% of American workers have traditional full-time jobs. They are half-time, part-time, contract workers, or temps. The term "side hustle" seems to capture the spirit of this era where people are combining multiple pursuits to make a living. The word "side hustle" has its roots in popular African American newspapers of the 1920s, where it referred to some kind of scam. By the 1950s, it was used to describe legitimate work as well. A side hustle differs from a second job in that it is not necessarily motivated by necessity.

original: Two twin domes, two radically opposed design cultures. One is made of thousands of steel parts, the other of a single silk thread. One is synthetic, the other organic. original: Hello. My name is simone. You know how people tell you if you get nervous when onstage, picture people in the audience naked? like it's this thing that's supposed to make you feel better. polished:
1. Practice, practice, practice, practice: The more you perform, the more comfortable you'll become with being on stage. Try to perform as often as you can, whether it's in front of a small audience or just by yourself in your living room.

2. Use visualization techniques: Close your eyes and imagine yourself on stage, surrounded by a sea of adoring fans. Visualize yourself feeling confident and comfortable, and try to tap into that feeling when you're on stage.3. Focus on your message: Instead of worrying about how you look, try to focus on the message you're trying to convey. Remember, you're up there to share something important, and the audience wants to hear it.4. Take deep breaths: Before you go on stage, take a few deep breaths to calm your nerves. This can help you relax and focus.5. Find a support system: Having a supportive team or group of friends can help you feel more at ease on stage. They can provide encouragement and help you feel more comfortable.

polished:
The idea that multitasking is a productive and efficient way to work is a common belief in modern society, but it is not necessarily supported by scientific evidence. In fact, research has shown that multitasking can actually decrease productivity and increase errors and mistakes.

Albert Einstein, one of the most renowned scientists in history, was a proponent of single-tasking. In 1905, he published four remarkable scientific papers, each of which he worked on exclusively and completed without interruption. This approach to work allowed him to focus his full attention on the task at hand and to produce work of the highest quality.
As for the idea that multitasking is necessary for important tasks, such as live tweeting or texting while driving, it is important to recognize that these activities are not the same as complex cognitive tasks that require sustained attention. While it may be possible to quickly send a message or post a brief update, doing so while engaged in other activities can be dangerous and can lead to errors and accidents. It is better to focus on one task at a time and to complete it to the best of one's ability before moving on to the next task.In conclusion, while multitasking may seem like a productive way to work, the scientific

original: Sustainability represents the what, the where and the how of what is caught. The who and the why are what's important to me. I want to know the people behind my dinner choices. I want to know how i impact them. I want to know how they impact me. I want to know why they fish. I want to know how they rely on the water's bounty for their living. Understanding all of this enables us to shift our perception of seafood away from a commodity to an opportunity to restore our ecosystem. It allows for us to celebrate the seafood that we're also so fortunate to eat.so what do we call this? i think we call it restorative seafood. Where sustainability is the capacity to endure and maintain, restorative is the ability to replenish and progress.
polished: Sustainability represents the what, the where, and the how of what is caught. The who and the why are what's important to me. I want to know the people behind my dinner choices. I want to know how they impact them. I want to know how they rely on the water's bounty for their living. Understanding all of this enables us to shift our perception of seafood away from a commodity to an opportunity to restore our ecosystem. It allows us to celebrate the seafood we're fortunate to eat. So, what do we call this? I think we call it restorative seafood. Sustainability is the capacity to endure and maintain, while restorative is the ability to replenish and progress.

original: The starving orphan seeking a second helping of gruel. The spinster wasting away in her tattered wedding dress. The stone-hearted miser plagued by the ghost of christmas past. original: There are currently hundreds of thousands of people on transplant lists, waiting for critical organs like kidneys, hearts, and livers that could save their lives. Unfortunately, there aren’t nearly enough donor organs available to fill that demand.what if instead of waiting, we could create brand-new, customized organs from scratch? that’s the idea behind bioprinting, a branch of regenerative medicine currently under development. We’re not able to print complex organs just yet, but simpler tissues including blood vessels and tubes responsible for nutrient and waste exchange are already in our grasp.bioprinting is a biological cousin of 3-d printing, a technique that deposits layers of material on top of each other to construct a three-dimensional object one slice at a time.
polished:
Bioprinting is a revolutionary technology that has the potential to revolutionize the field of organ transplantation by allowing for the creation of customized, artificial organs. Unlike traditional organ transplantation, which relies on finding a matching donor organ, bioprinting involves creating an organ from scratch using a patient's own cells. This eliminates the need for a donor organ shortage and reduces the risk of rejection, as the new organ will be made from the patient's own cells.

Bioprinting works by using a combination of cells, biomaterials, and bioinks to create a three-dimensional (3D) structure that mimics the structure and function of a real organ. The process starts with a detailed scan of the patient's body, which is used to create a digital model of the organ that needs to be replaced. This digital model is then used to create a "bioink" that is tailored to the specific needs of the patient. The bioink is a type of ink that contains living cells, such as stem cells, which are programmed to differentiate into the specific type of cells needed for the organ.

polished: In 1964, Bob Dylan was 23 years old and at the height of his career, churning out classic songs at an incredible pace. In 2004, Brian Burton, also known as Danger Mouse, took The Beatles' "White Album" and combined it with Jay-Z's "The Black Album" to create "The Grey Album." The mashup was an instant online sensation, but The Beatles' record company sent out numerous cease-and-desist letters for unfair competition and dilution of their valuable property. Today, "The Grey Album" is considered a remix.

This little metal ball, smaller than two feet in diameter, launched a space race between the u.s. And u.s.s.r. That would last for eighteen years and change the world as we know it. polished: On October 4, 1957, the world watched in awe and fear as the Soviet Union launched Sputnik, the world's first man-made satellite, into space. Sputnik was not the first piece of human technology to enter space, however. That superlative belongs to the V-2 rocket used by Germany in missile attacks against Allied cities as a last-ditch effort in the final years of World War II. original: Menstruation. A simple word describing a natural biological process, weighed down by centuries of stigma, has been transformed into something most of us can only speak about in whispers. But why? as i speak to you right now, more than 800 million women around the world are having a period. None of us would exist without it, and yet it remains an "embarrassing" subject to broach. From my experience and that of the women around me, i can tell you that it's exhausting.it's exhausting to carefully take out a brown paper bag hiding a pad, stuffing it into your pocket in the middle of a class and rushing to the washroom as discreetly as possible. It's exhausting to sit through lessons and meetings pretending to be absolutely normal, while internally crying out from intense period cramps.
polished: Menstruation: A natural biological process that affects over 800 million women worldwide, yet it remains a taboo subject in many cultures. Despite its prevalence, it's common to hear whispers or hushed tones when discussing menstruation. As I speak to you now, millions of women are experiencing their periods, yet it's often treated as an embarrassing or shameful topic. For many, it's a source of discomfort, from the physical symptoms to the social stigma surrounding it. From my perspective and that of the women I've spoken to, it's frustrating to have to navigate through daily life with the added burden of hiding and discretion. It's exhausting to have to carefully conceal sanitary products in a brown paper bag and rush to the bathroom, trying to avoid drawing attention to oneself. The stigma surrounding menstruation can make it difficult to focus on anything else, even during important meetings or classes, as the discomfort and embarrassment can be all-consuming.

original: I'd like to take you on the epic quest of the rosetta spacecraft. To escort and land the probe on a comet, this has been my passion for the past two years. In order to do that, i need to explain to you something about the origin of the solar system.when we go back four and a half billion years, there was a cloud of gas and dust. In the center of this cloud, our sun formed and ignited. Along with that, what we now know as planets, comets and asteroids formed. What then happened, according to theory, is that when the earth had cooled down a bit after its formation, comets massively impacted the earth and delivered water to earth. polished:
The origin of the solar system, including the formation of the Sun and the planets, is a complex and still somewhat debated topic in the scientific community. The general consensus among scientists is that the Sun formed about 4.6 billion years ago from the collapse of a giant cloud of gas and dust called a solar nebula. As the Sun formed, it ignited, and as it did, it began to heat up and eventually became hot enough to melt the surrounding material, forming the Sun and the planets.


The process of planetary formation is thought to have occurred through a process called accretion, in which small particles of rock and dust in the solar nebula stuck together and grew larger and larger through collisions and gravitational attraction. Over time, these particles formed larger and larger bodies, including the planets, dwarf planets, and other objects in the solar system.

The idea that comets and asteroids delivered water and complex organic material to Earth is supported by a number of lines of evidence, including the presence of water and organic compounds in meteorites, which are small rocks that have fallen to Earth from space. These meteorites are thought to be fragments of comets and asteroids that have broken apart and entered Earth's atmosphere, where they have burned up

original: In 1903, the president of the united states took a three-day camping trip in california’s yosemite valley. President theodore roosevelt slept in a grove of towering sequoia trees, camped in a snowstorm, and spent hours talking around the campfire with his host and guide, conservationist john muir. Roosevelt famously loved the outdoors, but muir had invited him there for more than just camping: yosemite was in danger.though yosemite became protected land in 1864, the valley was still at risk for overdevelopment in 1903. It was at the heart of a decades-old struggle to set aside land for both preservation and public use— two goals that were much easier said than done.the battle over yosemite began with the 1849 gold rush, when miners surged west, seeking gold in the sierra nevada foothills.
polished: In 1903, the President of the United States embarked on a three-day camping trip in California's Yosemite Valley. President Theodore Roosevelt slept among a grove of towering sequoia trees, endured a snowstorm, and spent hours engaging in lively conversation around the campfire with his host and guide, conservationist John Muir. Roosevelt, an ardent lover of the outdoors, was invited by Muir for more than just a camping trip; Yosemite was in danger of overdevelopment. Although the valley was protected land since 1864, it was still at risk of being overrun by developers in 1903. This was the culmination of a long-standing struggle to strike a balance between preservation and public use – two goals that proved challenging to achieve. The battle for Yosemite began in 1849 with the gold rush, when miners flocked west in search of gold in the Sierra Nevada foothills.

original: Imagine if you could plug your brain into a machine that would bring you ultimate pleasure for the rest of your life. If you were given the choice to sign up for that kind of existence, would you? that's the question philosopher robert nozick posed through a thought experiment he called the experience machine. The experiment asks us to consider a world in which scientists have developed a machine that would simulate real life while guaranteeing experiences of only pleasure and never pain. The catch? you have to permanently leave reality behind, but you'll hardly know the difference. Your experiences will be indistinguishable from reality. Life's natural ups and downs will just be replaced with an endless series of ups. Sounds great, right?
polished:
The thought experiment proposed by philosopher Robert Nozick, known as the "Experience Machine," raises questions about the nature of happiness and the value of reality. The idea is to imagine a world where scientists have developed a machine that can simulate real life experiences while guaranteeing only pleasure and never pain. The thought experiment asks us to consider whether we would choose to sign up for such an existence, where our experiences would be indistinguishable from reality, but with an endless supply of pleasure.
The idea of the experience machine is both intriguing and unsettling. On one hand, the thought of living a life without pain or hardship is certainly appealing. Who wouldn't want to avoid pain and suffering? On the other hand, the loss of free will and the potential loss of meaning and purpose that would result from living in a simulated reality is a difficult trade-off.The experience machine raises questions about the nature of happiness and what constitutes a good life. Is happiness solely about pleasure and enjoyment, or does it involve something more? Many philosophers argue that true happiness comes from meaningful experiences, relationships, and personal growth, rather than just pleasure. The experience machine would rob us of the opportunity to experience these deeper aspects of life.Furthermore, the experience machine raises questions about the nature of reality and the limits

original: I would like to tell you about the most embarrassing thing that has ever happened to me in my years of working as a palliative care physician. This happened a couple of years ago. polished:

She was a retired English professor and was experiencing pain, nausea, and vomiting. During the consultation, she asked me whether I thought medical marijuana might help her.
 I was taken aback by her question, as I had not had any exposure to medical marijuana in my training and had not been aware of its potential therapeutic benefits. I had to admit to her that I knew very little about it, and I thought back to everything I had learned in medical school about medical marijuana, which didn't take very long because I had learned absolutely nothing.

It's moments like these that remind me of the importance of staying up-to-date with the latest research and developments in the field of medicine, particularly when it comes to alternative therapies like medical marijuana. As firefighters, my team and I are tasked with saving lives and property from various disasters, including car wrecks, house fires, and life-threatening medical emergencies. As a woman leading a male-dominated profession, I have also seen firsthand the importance of having a diverse and inclusive workforce. Ten years ago, I decided to expand my medical knowledge and received a nursing degree. Realizing that the next major threat facing not only my city but other cities across the country, was not the one-and-done disaster, where we can simply ride in, put out the fire, and leave, feeling like we have made a difference and everything is okay, I recognized the need for a more comprehensive approach to emergency response.

original: Where does all the carbon we release go? carbon works in a natural cycle, present in all living things: in the soil, in the oceans, in the atmosphere and in rocks deep underground. When plants and other living things die, much of their stored carbon makes its way back to the atmosphere until new plants grow and reabsorb the carbon.but over millions of years, some of the carbon stored in ancient trees and sea life becomes rock and some becomes fossil fuels: coal, oil and natural gas. Natural events like volcanic eruptions release some of the carbon trapped in rock. And human activities, like burning fossil fuels, also release some of that prehistoric carbon.today, humans release around 60 times more carbon than all the volcanoes on the planet each year.
polished:
Here is a polished version of the text:
Carbon is a vital element that is present in all living things, including soil, oceans, and rocks. When plants and other living things die, their stored carbon is released back into the atmosphere, but some of it becomes fossil fuels like coal, oil, and natural gas. Natural events like volcanic eruptions release some of the carbon trapped in rocks, while human activities, such as burning fossil fuels, release much more than all the volcanoes on Earth combined. Today, humans release around 60 times more carbon than all the volcanoes on the planet each year.

Robust systems are stable in complex and new environments. Remarkably, cockroaches can self-stabilize running over rough terrain. When we put a jet pack on them, or give them a perturbation like an earthquake, we discovered that their wonderfully tuned legs allow them to self-stabilize without using any of their brainpower. They can go over complex terrain like grass, no problem, and not get destabilized. polished: Even nature's most unpleasant creatures hold secrets, yet who would welcome a swarm of cockroaches approaching? However, one of the key differences between natural and human technologies lies in resilience. Robust systems remain stable in unfamiliar and challenging environments. Remarkably, cockroaches can self-right while running over uneven terrain. When we added a jet pack or subjected them to an earthquake, we discovered that their exquisitely tuned limbs allowed them to self-right without expending any mental energy. They can effortlessly navigate complex terrain, such as grass, without becoming unstable. In fact, we observed a new behavior where, due to their shape, they automatically roll to the side to navigate this artificial test section of grass. Robust systems can perform multiple tasks with the same basic structure. Here's a new behavior we've discovered.

original: What is a parent?what is a parent?it's not an easy question. Today we have adoption, stepfamilies, surrogate mothers. Many parents face tough questions and tough decisions. Shall we tell our child about the sperm donation? if so, when? what words to use? sperm donors are often referred to as "biological fathers," but should we really be using the word "father? "as a philosopher and social scientist, i have been studying these questions about the concept of parenthood. But today, i will talk to you about what i learned from talking to parents and children. I will show you that they know what matters most in a family, even though their family looks a little different.
polished:
As a philosopher and social scientist, I have been studying the questions surrounding the concept of parenthood for some time now. However, I have come to realize that the language we use to talk about parenthood can be problematic, particularly when it comes to the term "father." While many people use the term "biological father" to refer to the male parent, it is important to recognize that this term can be alienating and invalidating for non-binary and genderqueer individuals and families.

For these individuals, the idea of a "biological father" does not necessarily align with their own experiences and identities. As such, it is important to use language that is inclusive and respectful of all families, regardless of their gender composition.
One way to do this is to use the term "parent" or "caregiver" instead of "father" when referring to the male or female parent. This language is more inclusive and acknowledges the important role that both parents play in a child's life.
Another important consideration is the use of language around the concept of "biological paternity." While this term is often used in legal and medical contexts, it can be harmful to assume that it is the only way to define paternity. polished: When I look in the mirror today, I see a justice and education scholar at Columbia University, a youth mentor, and a future New York State senator. (cheers) I see all of that and a man who spent a quarter of his life in state prison—six years, to be exact—starting as a teenager on Rikers Island for an act that nearly cost a man his life. But what got me from there to here wasn't the punishment I faced as a teenager in adult prison or the harshness of our legal system. Instead, it was a learning environment of a classroom that introduced me to something I didn't think was possible for me or our justice system as a whole. A few weeks before my release on parole, a counselor encouraged me to enroll in a new college course being offered in the prison.

It's not just about terrorism or extremism, it's about the way we perceive and treat each other as human beings.
"I want to challenge those negative perceptions and stereotypes that have been perpetuated in the media and in our society. I want to show that Muslims are not a monolithic group, but rather a diverse and vibrant community of people with different beliefs, practices, and cultures.

original: We need to build a weather service for water. Yet, until we collectively demand accountability, the incentives to fund it will not exist.the first time i spoke at a conference was here at ted, eight years ago. Fresh out of grad school, little did i know that in those few minutes onstage, i was framing the questions i was going to be asked for the next decade. And, like too many 20-somethings, i expected to solve the world's problems — more specifically, the world's water problems — with my technology. I had a lot to learn.it was seductive, believing that our biggest water quality problems persist because they're so hard to identify. And i presumed that we just needed simpler, faster and more affordable sensors. I was wrong.
polished:
Sure, here is a polished version of the text:
"We need to build a weather service for water. However, until we collectively demand accountability, the incentives to fund it will not exist. The first time I spoke at a conference was at TED, eight years ago. Fresh out of grad school, I had no idea that in those few minutes on stage, I was framing the questions I would be asked for the next decade. And, like many 20-somethings, I expected to solve the world's water problems — including the world's water quality problems — with my technology. I had a lot to learn. It was seductive to believe that our biggest water quality problems persist because they are so hard to identify. And I presumed that we just needed simpler, faster, and more affordable sensors. I was wrong.
